awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Ritual, Network Formation, and Governance among Displaced Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Anthropological science has long established that ritual plays an essential role in stabilizing the moral life of a community. And one area of social life where ritual is most critical is in the disposition of a community's dead. among This is of particular concern for communities that have been displaced by conflict, where death rates are exceptionally high, and individuals face insecurity and a daunting scarcity of physical and legal resources that challenge the social order. The research supported by this award, which supports the training of a graduate student in scientific methods of rigorous data collection and analysis, asks how host societies deal with the high number of displaced migrants' deaths, and what role mortuary and funerary practices have for displaced communities. According to the UNHCR, the world is witnessing the highest level of forced migration on record, making this a particularly appropriate time to examine this question. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, the project would improve scientific understanding by broadly disseminating its findings to organizations invested in discovering more effective means of delivering humanitarian aid. The project also broadens the participation of groups historically underrepresented in science, and builds capacity and scientific infrastructure through international cooperation among scientific research communities.

Foroogh Farhang, under the supervision of Dr. Jessica Winegar of Northwestern University, explores the extent to which mortuary and funerary practices are impacted by war and displacement, and what resources, networks, rituals, and relationships are marshaled in the burial and propitiation of the dead. The research takes place in Lebanon, where after seven years of civil war in neighboring Syria, displaced Syrians are the first refugee community with no formal camps and cemeteries. They have faced the increasingly stark challenges of securing one of the scarce number of burial sites and, further, holding a proper funeral for their dead. A lack of burial spaces, in conjunction with increasing restrictions on crossing the Lebanon-Syria border, have mobilized networks of Syrian burials within the borders of Lebanon and on the route from Lebanon to Syria. Because this involves such a sizable population, and the issue is so significantly culturally, this site proves an ideal laboratory for understanding what variables aid and inhibit cultural integration. Through in-depth, long-term, and on-site ethnographic fieldwork on people's mobility within Lebanon and between Lebanon and Syria, data will be collected through interviews, participant observation, life histories, and media research among representative samples of refugees, governmental and non-governmental staff, and local leaders and community members. Data will be subjected to thematic and content analysis in order to identify, quantify, and evaluate relevant codes and themes. This study draws upon classic anthropological concerns with ritual and death to examine whether its theoretical assumptions are influenced by variables that are acutely apparent in contemporary contexts marked by war, migration, refugee integration, and transnational NGOs. This research will contribute to debates in anthropology and the social sciences more broadly about mortuary and funerary practices, governance, mobility, and humanitarianism.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This study crucially brings a classic anthropological concern with ritual and death into the present moment by considering it in relation to war, migration, the state, and transnational NGOs. It investigates how the scarcity of burial spaces in Lebanon, along with increasing restrictions on crossing the Lebanon-Syria border, have mobilized legal and illegal networks for Syrians’ burials within Lebanon and on the route from Lebanon to Syria. With the support of the National Science Foundation, the PI and the Co-PI of this project offer a nuanced understanding of displaced Syrians’ alternative burial practices in the northern and eastern borderlands of Lebanon with Syria, where issues of life and death facing displaced communities in situations of war and resource scarcity can be best addressed.

The data collected during field research were subjected to thematic and content analysis to identify, quantify, and evaluate three relevant themes:

  1. Providing a deeper understanding of how Syrians navigate the proper burial of their loved ones and how, through these alternative modes of burial, new relationships between communities as well as new understandings of life, future, and belonging are cultivated.
  2. Investigating and identifying the benefits and limits of (non)governmental organizations’ services for Syrians’ burials and the effects of their shifting economic and legal frameworks on the burial crisis in the rapidly changing political climate of the Middle East.
  3. Analyzing how Lebanese encounters with Syrians’ burials are informed by and entangled with the political history of Lebanon and Syria, sectarianism, and kinship relations between the citizens of the two nation-states.

The ethnographic fieldwork conducted by the Co-PI in Lebanon involved participant observation, including cultural events, site visits to local cemeteries, home visits, funerals, community services in non-governmental organizations working with displaced and marginalized communities in Lebanon, media content analysis, and semi-structured interviews and life histories with displaced Syrians, local Lebanese, and governmental and non-governmental authorities.

Since the end of the data collection phase in December 2019, the Co-PI has started disseminating the findings of this project through academic and public-facing scholarship. The main outcomes of this project are published in the form of a PhD dissertation, successfully defended by the Co-PI and submitted to Northwestern University Library. The Co-PI has further disseminated the findings of this study in scholarly circles by submitting peer-reviewed articles to anthropological and interdisciplinary journals and by presenting at conferences such as the American Anthropological Association, Middle East Studies Association, and the European Association of Social Anthropologists. The Co-PI is also working on a book manuscript that will reflect the findings of this long-term qualitative research more deeply.

Beyond academic circles, the Co-PI has communicated the knowledge and outcomes of this project to non-profit organizations, policymakers, and international platforms. As a collaborator with the Chicago Council on Global Affairs and the Global Parliament of Mayors, she co-authored a policy paper on climate migration with the International Organization of Migration, co-created criteria for a book prize on urbanization, and wrote agendas, conducted research, drafted policy papers, and coordinated input from global stakeholders. During her field research in Lebanon, she collaborated with local and international non-profit organizations in their outreach activities and supported their policy implementation programs for the Syrian community in Beirut as well as the temporary Syrian refugee camps in the east and north of Lebanon. In 2018-19, in collaboration with the Center for Civic Engagement at the American University of Beirut, she developed curriculum for interdisciplinary humanities and social sciences courses and instructed 55 Syrian students preparing university and fellowship applications.

Through the juxtaposition of death and mobility, this project uniquely contributes to the growing and timely anthropological discussions on refugeehood and the relation between state power and subjects in the Middle East in two main ways. First, while echoing ethnographers’ attention to the refugee crisis in the region, it highlights the multilayered nature of Syrians’ presence in Lebanon to complicate the analytical distinctions between categories of refugee vs. migrant, political immigration vs. economic migration, forced vs. voluntary and legal vs. illegal. Second, by exploring the mobilization of people’s burial networks beyond the institutional confinements of the state or humanitarian agencies, it proposes that, in the face of the constraints of both national and transnational modes of institutionalized support and care, alternative networks of people make new forms of death, life, and future possible. In times of war and displacement, when death becomes an ever more constitutive part of everyday life, this ethnographic study examines burial practices to uncover the under-studied and lesser-recognized ways that displaced communities heal and survive.
